recipes.name: Sabudana Vada (Sago Patties)
ingredients: 1 cup sabudana (sago or tapioca pearls), soaked overnight and drained
½ cup peanuts, roasted and coarsely ground
1 to 2 tablespoons buckwheat flour or amaranth flour, optional
directions: Step 1: Start by soaking 1 cup of sabudana (sago) in water for 5 hours or overnight until it becomes soft.
Step 2: After soaking, ensure the sago pearls are tender without any hard center. Drain all excess water thoroughly to prevent soggy patties.

Step 3: Scrub and rinse 4 medium-sized potatoes. Boil the potatoes in a pressure cooker for 10 to 12 minutes or until tender. Alternatively, boil in a pan or an Instant Pot until fork-tender. Drain and let cool.
Step 4: Once the potatoes are cool, peel and mash them thoroughly.
Step 5: In a skillet, roast ½ cup of peanuts until crisp. Allow them to cool, then coarsely crush them using a mortar-pestle or grinder.

Step 6: In a mixing bowl, combine the soaked sabudana, mashed potatoes, coarsely ground peanuts, cumin seeds (if using), sugar, ginger, green chillies, coriander leaves, lemon juice, and rock salt. Mix thoroughly until well combined.
Step 7: Shape the mixture into flat round vadas or patties and set them aside.
Step 8: Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat. Test the oil with a small piece of the mixture; if it sizzles, it's ready.
Step 9: Gently place the vadas into the hot oil, without overcrowding. Fry them until golden and crisp, turning when necessary.
Step 10: Once cooked, remove the vadas with a slotted spoon and drain excess oil on paper towels.
Step 11: Serve the sabudana vada hot or warm.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant plate of golden-brown Sabudana Vada arranged artfully with a sprinkle of fresh coriander and a side of green chutney in a rustic wooden bowl. Use soft, diffused natural light to enhance the textures of the crispy patties, highlighting the glossy sheen of the chutney. Position the shot at a 45-degree angle to emphasize the layers and colors, with a shallow depth of field to softly blur the background. Incorporate a light, neutral linen tablecloth and a few scattered peanuts for added interest.

recipes.name: Medu Vada
ingredients: 1 cup split washed urad dal, soaked in water for 4-6 hours
directions: Step 1: Wash and soak the urad dal in about 3 cups of water for 4-6 hours.
Step 2: Drain the soaked dal and grind it into a smooth paste.
Step 3: Transfer the dal batter to a wide bowl and add the chopped cilantro, green chili, onion, salt, and asafoetida. Mix well.
Step 4: Beat the mixture vigorously for 2-3 minutes to make the batter light and fluffy and to ensure the right consistency.
Step 5: Ensure that the batter holds its shape when placed on your palm.
Step 6: Prepare the batter just before frying. Heat oil in a frying pan over medium-high heat, allowing about 1 inch of oil.
Step 7: To test if the oil is ready, drop a small amount of batter into it; it should sizzle and rise to the surface without changing color immediately.
Step 8: Wet your palms, take a golf ball-sized portion of batter, flatten it in your palm, and make a hole in the center using your other hand's fingers.
Step 9: Slowly slide the vada into the hot oil and fry until golden brown on both sides.
Step 10: Remove the vadas and place them on paper towels to drain excess oil. Serve hot with coconut chutney or tomato ketchup.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a stunning close-up of Medu Vada, showcasing the golden-brown, crispy exterior and soft, fluffy interior. Use natural light from a side window to highlight the textures and vibrant green flecks of cilantro. Style the dish on a rustic wooden board, garnished with fresh cilantro and a small bowl of coconut chutney. Incorporate a blurred background of colorful spices in small bowls for depth. Focus on the vada with a shallow depth of field to create an inviting, warm mood.

video_script.title: How to Make Medu Vada: A South Indian Delight
video_script.description: Learn how to make crispy and fluffy Medu Vada, a popular South Indian snack perfect for any occasion!

scenes.voice_over: For this recipe, we need 1 cup of soaked urad dal, a pinch of asafoetida, chopped green chili, finely chopped onion, fresh cilantro, and salt. Don't forget the oil for frying!

scenes.voice_over: Beat the mixture vigorously for 2 to 3 minutes. This aerates the batter, making it light and fluffy.

scenes.image_prompt: A frying pan with hot oil, and a small piece of batter dropped into it to test the temperature.
scenes.voice_over: Heat oil in a frying pan over medium-high heat, about 1 inch deep. Test the oil by dropping a small batter ball; it should sizzle.

scenes.voice_over: Wet your palms and take a golf ball-sized portion of the batter. Flatten it and make a hole in the center.

scenes.image_prompt: The shaped vada carefully sliding into the hot oil, with bubbles forming around it.
scenes.voice_over: Gently slide the shaped vada into the hot oil and fry until golden brown on both sides, about 3-4 minutes.

scenes.voice_over: Serve your hot and crispy Medu Vada with coconut chutney or tomato ketchup for a delightful snack!

cooking_tips: Ensure the batter is not too thick or too thin for optimal frying.
Using fresh ingredients enhances the flavor of the vadas.

recipes.name: Dahi Vada
ingredients: 1/2 cup urad dal, soaked for 4 hours
1/2 cup moong dal, soaked for 4 hours
1/2 cup milk, for thinning the yogurt
2 teaspoons cumin seeds (jeera), toasted and crushed, adjust to taste
Oil for deep frying, as needed
directions: Step 1: Soak the urad dal and moong dal in water for 4 hours, then drain.
Step 2: Blend the soaked dals in a blender on medium speed, adding minimal water to achieve a smooth paste.
Step 3: Add salt to taste to the dal mixture and heat oil in a deep frying pan.
Step 4: Once the oil is hot, drop spoonfuls of the batter into the oil, frying until they are golden brown on all sides.
Step 5: Remove the fried vadas and place them in a bowl of water to soak until ready to serve.
Step 6: In a separate bowl, beat the yogurt with the milk to achieve a smooth consistency, adding crushed cumin seeds and adjusting spice levels as desired.
Step 7: Gently squeeze the soaked vadas to remove excess water, then layer them on a serving platter and top with the yogurt mixture. Serve immediately.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a high-quality image of Dahi Vada with a soft-focus background to highlight the dish's creamy yogurt and golden-brown vadas. Use natural light from the side to enhance textures, emphasizing the contrast between the crispy exterior and the soft interior. Style with a rustic wooden table and a slate backdrop, garnished with fresh cilantro and a sprinkle of crushed cumin. Shoot at a 45-degree angle with a shallow depth of field to draw attention to the vadas, creating a warm, inviting mood.

recipes.name: Masala Vada - Spicy Lentil Fritters
ingredients: 1 cup chana dal (soaked for 2 to 3 hours and drained)
10 small onions or 1 large onion (finely chopped)
3 to 4 tablespoons fresh coriander leaves (finely chopped)
directions: Step 1: Wash and soak the chana dal in water for 2 to 3 hours, then drain the water and set aside.
Step 2: In a blender, grind the ginger, garlic, red chillies, and fennel seeds into a coarse paste.
Step 3: Grind the soaked chana dal into a coarse mixture, ensuring that some pieces remain whole. Transfer to a mixing bowl.

Step 4: Add the chopped onions, rice flour or semolina, coriander leaves, salt, and the ground spice paste to the chana dal mixture. Mix thoroughly without adding water. The mixture should be crumbly but should hold together when formed into balls.
Step 5: Form the mixture into lemon-sized balls and gently flatten them to form thick patties.
Step 6: Arrange the patties on a plate, ready for frying.
Step 7: Heat oil in a kadai (deep frying pan) over medium heat. Once hot, carefully drop the patties into the oil in batches.
Step 8: Deep fry the patties until they are golden brown, turning them halfway to ensure even cooking. Drain on paper towels before serving.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant overhead shot of crispy Masala Vada arranged artfully on a rustic wooden platter, garnished with fresh coriander leaves and accompanied by a small bowl of tangy green chutney. Use natural light to accentuate the golden-brown textures and deep colors of the fritters. Incorporate a soft-focus background of textured fabric in warm earth tones to enhance warmth. Use a shallow depth of field to draw attention to the vadas, creating a cozy, inviting mood that evokes the essence of traditional Indian street food.

recipes.name: Vada Pav - Spicy Potatoes in a Bun
ingredients: 10 medium potatoes, boiled, peeled, and mashed
1/3 cup vegetable oil or canola oil, for frying
1/2 cup shengdaana lehsun chutney (peanut garlic chutney)
directions: Step 1: Gather all the ingredients.
Step 2: In a large mixing bowl, combine besan flour with enough water and salt to create a thick, smooth batter. Add water gradually until the consistency resembles thick soup.
Step 3: In a food processor, blend the ginger and garlic pastes along with the chopped green chiles to form a smooth mixture.
Step 4: Incorporate the green chili paste into the mashed potatoes and season with salt.
Step 5: Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pan over medium heat, then add black mustard seeds, curry leaves, and turmeric powder. Fry until the mustard seeds stop spluttering.
Step 6: Transfer the spice mixture to the mashed potato mixture and combine thoroughly.
Step 7: Divide the potato mixture into portions slightly smaller than a tennis ball, shaping them into smooth balls by rolling between greased palms.
Step 8: Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat for frying.
Step 9: Once the oil is hot, dip each potato ball into the besan batter, coating it evenly, then fry until golden brown. Drain them on paper towels.
Step 10: Take a pav bun, slit it open, and spread a spoonful of tamarind chutney, green chutney, and shengdaana lehsun chutney on each half.
Step 11: Place a hot potato ball inside the bun, gently pressing it down, and serve immediately.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant Vada Pav against a rustic wooden table backdrop, emphasizing the golden-brown, crispy potato fritter nestled within a soft, slightly toasted bun. Use natural light to accentuate the textures of the spicy filling and the contrasting colors of fresh green chiles and curry leaves as garnishes. Style with a small bowl of tangy chutney on the side and a few scattered mustard seeds. Shoot from a low angle to create depth, focusing on the fritter, with a shallow depth of field to blur the background slightly, evoking a warm, inviting mood.

scenes.text: Blend garlic, ginger, and green chiles.
scenes.voice_over: Next, blend ginger and garlic pastes along with the chopped green chiles in a food processor until you have a smooth mixture.

scenes.text: Combine green chili paste into mashed potatoes.

scenes.voice_over: Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a pan over medium heat, then add the black mustard seeds, curry leaves, and turmeric powder. Fry until the mustard seeds stop spluttering.

scenes.voice_over: Heat oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat. Once hot, dip each potato ball in the besan batter and fry until golden brown, around 5-6 minutes.

scenes.text: Prepare the pav buns with chutneys.
scenes.voice_over: Take a pav bun, slit it open, and spread tamarind chutney, green chutney, and shengdaana lehsun chutney on each half.

cooking_tips: Ensure the oil is hot enough before frying to achieve a crispy texture.
Adjust the spice level by using more or fewer green chiles based on your preference.

recipes.name: Vada Fritters
ingredients: 1 1/2 cups split, skin-on moong daal, soaked overnight and drained
1 green chile pepper, chopped (adjust according to heat preference)
1/2 to 1 teaspoon red chili powder, optional
3 tablespoons Bengal gram flour (besan), plus more if needed
Vegetable or canola oil, for frying
1/2 cup finely chopped fresh coriander leaves
directions: Step 1: Rinse the split moong daal under running water until the water runs clear.
Step 2: Place the washed moong daal in a large bowl and cover it with warm water. Allow the daal to soak overnight.
Step 3: The following morning, drain the excess water from the soaked daal.

Step 4: In a food processor, combine the soaked moong daal, garlic, ginger, green chile, asafetida, and salt. Blend without adding water until a thick batter forms. If needed, add water gradually and blend until a medium-fine coarse batter is achieved.
Step 5: If the batter is too runny, mix in additional Bengal gram flour to thicken it.
Step 6: Heat vegetable or canola oil in a wok or deep pan over medium heat for frying.
Step 7: To check the oil's readiness, drop a small amount of batter into the hot oil. If it rises to the surface slowly and does not burn, the oil is ready.
Step 8: Once the oil is ready, use a teaspoon to scoop small balls of batter and carefully drop them into the hot oil, avoiding overcrowding the pan.
Step 9: Use a slotted spoon to gently turn the fritters occasionally for even browning. Fry until they turn deep golden brown.
Step 10: Remove the fritters from the oil using a slotted spoon and drain them on a kitchen towel to remove excess oil. Sprinkle lightly with chaat masala.
Step 11: Serve the vada fritters with mint-coriander chutney and tamarind chutney alongside a cup of steaming adrak ki chai.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant overhead shot of Vada Fritters arranged artfully on a rustic wooden board, surrounded by fresh green herbs and sliced red onions for color contrast. Utilize soft, natural light to enhance the golden-brown texture of the fritters, while casting gentle shadows. Incorporate a small bowl of tangy chutney as a prop, and sprinkle a touch of red chili powder on the plate for added visual interest. Use a shallow depth of field to softly blur the background, drawing focus to the fritters and creating an inviting, warm mood.

recipes.name: Parippu Vada - Spicy Lentil Fritters
ingredients: 1/2 cup yellow lentils (thuvara parippu/toor dal), soaked for 3 hours and drained
1 sprig of curry leaves, finely chopped
directions: Step 1: Soak the yellow lentils in water for three hours, then drain thoroughly.
Step 2: Grind the soaked lentils coarsely to maintain texture, ensuring not to make a smooth paste.
Step 3: In a mixing bowl, add the ground lentils, chopped red onion, green chilies, ginger, asafoetida, curry leaves, and salt. Mix all ingredients well.
Step 4: Shape the mixture into small discs, ensuring they are no thicker than 1 cm at the center.
Step 5: Heat coconut oil in a frying pan over medium heat. Once hot, carefully add the lentil discs, ensuring not to overcrowd the pan.
Step 6: Fry the vadas on one side until they are golden brown, then flip them over to cook the other side until brown and crispy.
Step 7: Remove the fritters from the pan and drain excess oil on a paper towel before serving.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up shot of golden-brown Parippu Vada arranged artfully on a rustic wooden platter, surrounded by fresh curry leaves and a small bowl of tangy coconut chutney. Use natural light to enhance the fritters’ crispy texture and vibrant colors, casting soft shadows for depth. Employ a shallow depth of field to keep the focus on the fritters while softly blurring the background. Style with a textured linen napkin and scattered red chili flakes for an authentic touch, evoking a warm, inviting mood.

video_script.title: Parippu Vada - Spicy Lentil Fritters Recipe
video_script.description: Learn how to make crispy and spicy Parippu Vada, a delicious South Indian snack made from lentils.

scenes.image_prompt: A beautifully plated dish of Parippu Vada with a vibrant green chutney and colorful garnishes, showcasing the crispy texture and golden brown color of the fritters.
scenes.text: Welcome to our kitchen! Today, we're making Parippu Vada.
scenes.voice_over: Welcome to our kitchen! Today we’re making Parippu Vada, delightful spicy lentil fritters that are crispy and packed with flavor.

scenes.image_prompt: All the ingredients laid out on a wooden countertop: yellow lentils, red onion, green chilies, ginger, asafoetida, curry leaves, salt, and coconut oil.
scenes.text: Let's check the ingredients we need.
scenes.voice_over: For this recipe, you will need yellow lentils, red onion, green chilies, ginger, asafoetida, curry leaves, salt, and coconut oil for frying.

scenes.image_prompt: A bowl of soaked yellow lentils being drained in a colander.
scenes.voice_over: First, soak half a cup of yellow lentils in water for three hours, then drain them thoroughly to remove excess water.

scenes.image_prompt: A food processor with soaked lentils being ground coarsely, showing a rough texture.
scenes.voice_over: Next, grind the soaked lentils coarsely. You want a texture, not a smooth paste, to ensure the fritters hold together.

scenes.image_prompt: A mixing bowl filled with the ground lentils and chopped ingredients: onions, chilies, ginger, curry leaves, and asafoetida, with a pinch of salt.
scenes.text: Step 3: Mix all the ingredients well.
scenes.voice_over: In a mixing bowl, add the coarsely ground lentils, chopped red onion, green chilies, ginger, a pinch of asafoetida, chopped curry leaves, and salt. Mix everything well until combined.

scenes.image_prompt: Hands shaping a small disc from the lentil mixture, showing the size and thickness needed.
scenes.voice_over: Now, shape the mixture into small discs, about 1 cm thick at the center. This ensures they cook evenly.

scenes.image_prompt: A frying pan with hot coconut oil, several lentil discs being carefully placed in the oil.
scenes.voice_over: Heat coconut oil in a frying pan over medium heat. Once hot, carefully add the lentil discs, making sure not to overcrowd the pan.

scenes.image_prompt: Golden brown fritters frying in oil, one being flipped over, showing the crispiness.
scenes.voice_over: Fry the vadas on one side until they are golden brown, then flip them over and cook the other side until crispy and brown, about 3-4 minutes per side.

scenes.image_prompt: A plate of freshly fried Parippu Vada on paper towels absorbing excess oil.
scenes.voice_over: Once fried, remove the fritters from the pan and drain the excess oil on paper towels before serving.

scenes.image_prompt: Final presentation of the Parippu Vada served with a side of green chutney and garnished with fresh herbs.
scenes.voice_over: Enjoy your crispy and spicy Parippu Vada with a refreshing side of chutney. Perfect as a snack or an appetizer!

cooking_tips: Ensure the oil is hot enough before adding the fritters to achieve a crunchy texture.
Adjust the number of green chilies based on your spice preference.

recipes.name: Moong Dal Vada
ingredients: ½ cup whole moong dal (payatham paruppu, whole green gram), soaked overnight
¼ cup chana dal (kadalai paruppu, split Bengal gram), soaked overnight
directions: Step 1: Combine the soaked moong dal and chana dal in a bowl. Fill with enough water and soak overnight. The next day, drain the water completely.
Step 2: Grind the soaked dals in a mixer to a coarse paste without adding water.
Step 3: Transfer the coarse paste to a mixing bowl. Add the chopped onions, green chilies, ginger-garlic paste, asafoetida, and salt. Mix everything well and let it rest for 10 minutes.
Step 4: Heat oil in a heavy-bottomed kadai for deep frying. Once the oil is hot, make small balls from the vada batter and carefully drop them into the hot oil.
Step 5: Fry the vadas until they turn golden brown and crispy, about 4-5 minutes.
Step 6: Remove the vadas carefully from the oil and drain any excess oil using absorbent tissue paper.
Step 7: Serve the hot vadas with coconut chutney.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up of golden-brown Moong Dal Vada arranged artfully on a rustic wooden platter, garnished with fresh coriander and a side of green chutney. Use soft, diffused natural light to enhance the vibrant colors and crispy texture. Incorporate a textured linen napkin and a small bowl of sliced red onions for contrast. Focus on a shallow depth of field to blur the background, drawing attention to the vada's intricate details and creating a warm, inviting mood.

video_script.title: Delicious Moong Dal Vada Recipe
video_script.description: Learn how to make crispy and flavorful Moong Dal Vada with this easy step-by-step tutorial!

scenes.image_prompt: A beautifully arranged plate of golden brown Moong Dal Vada served with coconut chutney and garnished with fresh coriander.

scenes.image_prompt: A bowl of soaked moong dal and chana dal being mixed with water, emphasizing the soaking process.
scenes.voice_over: Step 1: Combine the soaked moong dal and chana dal in a bowl and soak overnight. Drain completely in the morning.

scenes.image_prompt: A blender grinding the soaked dals into a coarse paste with close-up of textured consistency.
scenes.voice_over: Step 2: Grind the soaked dals in a mixer to a coarse paste without adding any water.

scenes.image_prompt: A mixing bowl with the coarse dal paste being added to chopped onions, green chilies, and spices, all coming together.
scenes.voice_over: Step 3: Transfer the paste to a bowl, add onions, green chilies, ginger-garlic paste, asafoetida, and salt. Mix well and let it rest for 10 minutes.

scenes.image_prompt: A pot filled with oil on a stovetop with bubbling oil, ready for frying.
scenes.voice_over: Step 4: Heat oil in a heavy-bottomed kadai for deep frying until hot, around 350 degrees Fahrenheit.

scenes.image_prompt: Small balls of the vada batter being carefully dropped into the hot oil, creating bubbles.
scenes.voice_over: Step 5: Make small balls from the batter and carefully drop them into the hot oil. Fry until golden brown and crispy, about 4-5 minutes.

scenes.image_prompt: Fried vadas being lifted out of the oil using a slotted spoon and placed onto absorbent tissue paper.
scenes.voice_over: Step 6: Remove the vadas carefully and drain the excess oil on absorbent tissue paper.

scenes.image_prompt: A serving of Moong Dal Vada on a plate alongside coconut chutney with a garnish of coriander.
scenes.voice_over: Step 7: Serve hot vadas with coconut chutney. Enjoy this crispy snack!

cooking_tips: Make sure the dal is soaked overnight for optimal texture.
Do not add water while grinding to achieve the right consistency.
Ensure the oil is hot enough for frying to avoid soggy vadas.

recipes.name: Crispy Baked Potato Vadas
ingredients: 4 medium russet potatoes, boiled, peeled, and mashed with a fork
directions: Step 1: In a large mixing bowl, combine all the ingredients and mix well until the mixture can hold together when shaped into balls.
Step 2: Using your fingers, shape the mixture into 1.5-inch patties (approximately 2 cm wide) ensuring they are neither too thick nor too thin.
Step 3: Prepare a baking sheet by lining it with parchment paper and preheat the oven to 450°F (232°C).
Step 4: Lightly spray the parchment paper with oil and arrange the patties on the sheet, ensuring they are spaced at least 1 inch apart. Spray the tops of the patties with additional oil.
Step 5: Place the baking sheet in the preheated oven and bake the patties for 20 minutes.
Step 6: After 20 minutes, carefully flip the vadas over and continue baking for another 20 minutes or until they are golden brown and crispy.
Step 7: Remove the vadas from the oven and serve them hot with your favorite chutney.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant, high-angle shot of crispy baked potato vadas arranged artfully on a rustic wooden board. Highlight the golden-brown texture with soft, diffused natural light to enhance the dish's colors. Use a blurred green herb garnish, like cilantro or mint, in the foreground for depth, while a few scattered curry leaves and whole spices add interest in the background. A simple, neutral linen napkin complements the scene, creating a warm, inviting mood. Focus on the vadas' crisp exterior while keeping the background softly out of focus to draw attention to the dish.

Feel free to customize the spice level by adjusting the amount of pepper used.

recipes.name: Fat-Free Tapioca Pearl Fritters (Sabudana Vada)
ingredients: 1 cup tapioca pearls, soaked in water for 4 hours, then drained
1 large russet potato, boiled, peeled, and mashed
2 green chilies, finely minced (seeds removed for less heat)
¼ cup fresh coriander leaves, chopped
directions: Step 1: In a large mixing bowl, combine all ingredients and knead by hand until a cohesive dough forms.

Step 2: If using a food processor, add all ingredients to the bowl and pulse briefly—two to three times for no more than five seconds each—until the dough comes together. If the mixture is too dry, add a teaspoon of water at a time until it holds together.
Step 3: Spray an ebelskiver pan or a griddle with fat-free cooking spray, or brush lightly with oil.

Step 4: For the ebelskiver pan, shape the mixture into rounded fritters and press them into the pan cavities. For a griddle, dampen your palms with water and shape the fritters into flat discs to ensure even contact with the cooking surface.
Step 5: Cook the fritters for about 2-3 minutes until the bottom is golden brown, then flip them carefully.
Step 6: Cook the other side until it is also golden brown, pressing down slightly with a spoon if using the ebelskiver pan to ensure proper contact with the surface.
Step 7: Serve the fritters hot with your choice of chutney.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant overhead shot of Fat-Free Tapioca Pearl Fritters arranged artistically on a rustic wooden board. Use natural light to enhance the golden-brown crispiness and vibrant green of the coriander. Surround the fritters with scattered curry leaves and a small bowl of tangy chutney for contrast. Incorporate a linen napkin in a soft pastel color beneath the dish. Use a shallow depth of field to keep the fritters in sharp focus while softly blurring the background, evoking a warm, inviting mood.

video_script.title: Fat-Free Tapioca Pearl Fritters (Sabudana Vada) Recipe
video_script.description: Learn how to make delicious and healthy Fat-Free Tapioca Pearl Fritters, ideal for snacking or as a side dish. Perfectly crispy and packed with flavor!

recipes.name: Bajri Methi Dhebra
directions: 1. In a large mixing bowl, combine millet flour, chopped fenugreek leaves, coriander powder, red chili powder, turmeric powder, curd, sesame seeds, and salt.
2. Gradually add water and knead the mixture into a slightly stiff and smooth dough, similar to paratha dough.
3. Grease your palms with oil and pinch a lemon-sized portion from the dough, rolling it into a ball shape. Repeat with the remaining dough to make approximately 15 balls.
4. Flatten each ball into a circle with a diameter of 3 inches, approximately 2/3 cm thick, either by pressing between your palms or rolling it out on a plastic sheet.
5. Heat oil in a frying pan over medium flame. Once the oil is medium hot, slide 3-4 flattened circles into it.
6. Fry the circles until they turn light golden brown on both sides, then transfer them to a plate lined with oil-absorbent paper to soak up excess oil.
7. Repeat the frying process with the remaining dhebra.
8. Bajri na dhebra is ready to serve hot with curd and pickle, making it a perfect accompaniment for dinner or a healthy evening snack.
9. For a variation, add an extra 0.5 cup of wheat flour to the initial ingredients. Divide the dough into 10 equal portions, shaping them into rounds.
10. Roll out each dough portion into a circle 6-7 inches in diameter, sprinkling some dry flour to prevent sticking.
11. Heat a non-stick tava (griddle) over medium flame. Cook the rolled circle, flipping it occasionally and applying 0.5 teaspoon of oil on each side until light brown spots appear.
12. Serve bajri na dhebra hot with tea.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture Bajri Methi Dhebra arranged on a rustic wooden board, garnished with fresh fenugreek leaves and a sprinkle of sesame seeds. Use warm, natural lighting to accentuate the golden-brown crust and vibrant green hues. Position a small bowl of yogurt with a drizzle of olive oil beside the dish. Opt for a slight overhead angle to highlight the dish's texture while keeping the foreground in sharp focus and the background softly blurred, creating an inviting, homely mood.

recipes.name: Coconut Milk Paniyaram
ingredients: 1/2 cup raw rice, soaked for 2-3 hours
1/2 cup whole urad dal, soaked for 2-3 hours
1 cup coconut milk, fresh or canned
directions: Step 1: Soak the raw rice and urad dal together for 2-3 hours in enough water.
Step 2: Drain the soaked mixture and grind it to a fine batter in a grinder, adding water sparingly to achieve a thick consistency.
Step 3: Add a tiny pinch of salt to the batter, mix well, and set aside.
Step 4: Heat oil in a kadai or deep frying pan over medium heat.
Step 5: Once the oil is hot, take small portions of the batter and gently drop them into the oil.
Step 6: Fry the paniyarams until they puff up and turn light golden on both sides, then remove and drain on tissue paper.
Step 7: In a mixing bowl, combine coconut milk, boiled and cooled milk, cardamom powder, and sugar. Mix well.
Step 8: Gently drop the fried paniyarams into the prepared milk mixture and let them soak for 5-10 minutes before serving.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a top-down view of golden-brown Coconut Milk Paniyaram arranged artfully on a rustic wooden board. Use vibrant, tropical-themed props like fresh coconut halves and banana leaves to enhance the dish's exotic appeal. Employ soft, diffused natural light to emphasize the glossy texture of the paniyaram and the creamy coconut milk. Include a shallow depth of field to blur the background slightly, drawing focus to the paniyaram, while a sprig of mint adds a fresh pop of color for garnish.

video_script.title: Delicious Coconut Milk Paniyaram Recipe
video_script.description: Learn how to make this delightful and fluffy Coconut Milk Paniyaram, perfect for a snack or dessert! Join us for step-by-step cooking instructions.

scenes.text: Soak raw rice and urad dal.
scenes.voice_over: Start by soaking the raw rice and urad dal together for 2-3 hours in enough water.

scenes.image_prompt: An electric grinder with soaked rice and urad dal being added to it, ready for grinding.
scenes.voice_over: Next, drain the soaked mixture and grind it to a fine batter, adding water sparingly to achieve a thick consistency.

scenes.image_prompt: A bowl with the freshly ground batter being seasoned with a tiny pinch of salt.
scenes.voice_over: Add a tiny pinch of salt to the batter and mix well before setting it aside.

scenes.image_prompt: A kadai with hot oil bubbling, ready for frying the paniyarams.
scenes.voice_over: Heat oil in a kadai or deep frying pan over medium heat until it is hot and ready.

scenes.image_prompt: Small portions of the batter being carefully dropped into the hot oil, causing gentle bubbles.
scenes.voice_over: Once the oil is hot, take small portions of the batter and gently drop them into the oil. Fry until they puff up and turn light golden on both sides.

scenes.image_prompt: Golden fried paniyarams being lifted from the oil and placed on tissue paper to drain.
scenes.voice_over: Remove the fried paniyarams and drain them on tissue paper to absorb excess oil.

scenes.voice_over: In a mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of coconut milk, 1/3 cup of boiled and cooled milk, 1/4 teaspoon of cardamom powder, and 1/8 cup of sugar. Mix well.

scenes.image_prompt: Fried paniyarams being gently placed in the milk mixture, soaking up the flavors.
scenes.voice_over: Gently drop the fried paniyarams into the prepared milk mixture and let them soak for 5-10 minutes.

cooking_tips: Make sure the oil is hot enough before adding the batter, to ensure they puff up properly.
Soak the batter until it's fluffy for the best texture.

recipes.name: Sambhar: Indian Spiced Lentil Vegetable Stew
ingredients: 2 cups split yellow pigeon peas, rinsed
1 tablespoon tamarind pulp, soaked in hot water
1/4 cup fresh coriander leaves, chopped, for garnish
directions: Step 1: In a large pot, boil the rinsed pigeon peas and sambar masala with enough water until soft, achieving a thick soup consistency.
Step 2: Soak the tamarind pulp in a small bowl of hot water for 10 minutes. Squeeze it to extract all the juice.
Step 3: Add the tamarind juice to the cooked lentils and mix well. Adjust salt to taste.
Step 4: Add the potato cubes to the lentils and simmer until they are half cooked.
Step 5: Incorporate the remaining vegetables and optional drumsticks, cooking until all are tender.
Step 6: In a small pan, heat the ghee and add the curry leaves, dry red chilies, and mustard seeds. Fry until the mustard seeds start to splutter, then pour this tempering into the lentil mixture.
Step 7: Stir well and garnish with chopped coriander leaves. Serve hot with idlis, vadas, or plain boiled rice.

nutrition.sodium: assume varies based on added salt

Use soft, diffused natural light to enhance the textures of the ingredients, casting gentle shadows. Style the dish with a sprinkle of fresh cilantro on top and serve it in an earthy, rustic bowl, placed on a weathered wooden table. video_script.title: Sambhar: Indian Spiced Lentil Vegetable Stew
video_script.description: Learn how to make authentic Sambhar, a flavorful Indian stew made with lentils and a variety of vegetables!

scenes.image_prompt: A beautifully plated bowl of steaming Sambhar topped with fresh coriander leaves, served with idlis and vadas on the side.
scenes.text: Welcome to Sambhar, the spicy lentil stew!
scenes.voice_over: Today, we will be making a delicious Sambhar, packed with flavors and vegetables.

scenes.image_prompt: A clear counter showing grouped ingredients: split yellow pigeon peas, sambar masala, tamarind, potatoes, eggplant, pearl onions, okra, drumsticks, pumpkin, ghee, curry leaves, dry chilies, mustard seeds, and fresh coriander.
scenes.text: Here are the ingredients you'll need.
scenes.voice_over: For this recipe, we'll use split yellow pigeon peas, sambar masala, tamarind pulp, and a variety of vegetables including potatoes, eggplant, and okra.

scenes.image_prompt: A large pot boiling on a stove with yellow pigeon peas and spices visible, steam rising.
scenes.voice_over: In a large pot, boil 2 cups of rinsed pigeon peas with 4 tablespoons of sambar masala and enough water until soft, reaching a thick soup consistency.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of tamarind pulp soaking in a small bowl of hot water, with hands squeezing it to extract juice.
scenes.voice_over: Soak 1 tablespoon of tamarind pulp in hot water for 10 minutes. Squeeze it out to extract all the juice.

scenes.image_prompt: A mixing bowl with cooked lentils and tamarind juice being mixed in, with seasoning sprinkled on top.
scenes.voice_over: Mix the tamarind juice into the cooked lentils and adjust salt to taste.

scenes.image_prompt: Cut potatoes being added to the pot of lentils, with steam rising and veggies around the pot.
scenes.voice_over: Add 1 cup of potato cubes to the lentils and simmer until they are half cooked, about 5-7 minutes.

scenes.image_prompt: Various chopped vegetables being added to the pot, colorful and vibrant.
scenes.voice_over: Add eggplant, pearl onions, okra, and optional drumsticks, and cook until all the vegetables are tender.

scenes.image_prompt: A small pan with ghee heating up, surrounded by mustard seeds, curry leaves, and red chilies.
scenes.voice_over: In a separate pan, heat 3 tablespoons of ghee, add curry leaves, dry red chilies, and mustard seeds. Fry until the mustard seeds splutter.

scenes.image_prompt: Pouring the tempering into the pot of lentils, mixing it in beautifully with colorful veggies.
scenes.voice_over: Pour the tempering into the lentil mixture, stir well, and garnish with chopped coriander leaves.

scenes.image_prompt: Final serving of Sambhar in a vibrant bowl, with idlis and vadas on the side, garnished with coriander.
scenes.voice_over: Serve the hot Sambhar with idlis, vadas, or plain boiled rice for a complete meal!

cooking_tips: For a richer flavor, cook the lentils in vegetable broth instead of water.
Adjust the level of sambar masala to your taste for spiciness.
